On October 12, 1960, the killing was broadcast live by NHK television.TokyoReporter.com, "Assassin of Inejiro Asanuma remembered by right-wing groups on 50-year anniversary," October 14, 2010; retrieved 2012-3-15. ==Assassin== Yamaguchi was an assassin because he killed a politically active man. His reasons for the murder were political. Yamaguchi was a member of a radical group. In 1960, he killed Inejiro Asanuma, a Socialist, when he was at a public meeting. Soon after, Yamaguchi killed himself in a juvenile center. He wrote on the wall of the room in which he hung himself. His last words were written using a paste made from tooth powder and water. "Leftist's Killer Suicide in Japan; Young Rightist Who Stabbed Asanuma Hangs Himself in Detention Center," New York Times. November 3, 1960; "Assassin's Apologies," Time. November 14, 1960; retrieved 2012-3-15. He wrote "Seven lives for my country ..." which was a reference to the last words of 14th century samurai Kusunoki Masashige. ===Legacy=== Yasushi Nagao captured the assassination in a dramatic photograph. The image won the 1960 World Press Photo award. 1960 World Press Photo by Yasushi Nagao; retrieved 2012-3-15. Nobel Prize-winning writer Kenzaburō Ōe based his book Seventeen on Yamaguchi.Remmick, David. "Reading Japan," New Yorker.
